samples.context: In this osmosis experiment, four peeled potato halves are prepared as potato cups, with one cup made from a boiled potato. They are all placed in a trough of water to observe the effects of osmosis.
samples.question: What is the purpose of using boiled potato?

samples.context: Each potato cup is placed in water to see how osmosis affects the potatoes over time. The experiment aims to investigate water movement through semi-permeable membranes.
samples.question: What does osmosis refer to in this experiment?

samples.context: Boiled and raw potato cups are submerged in water to help visualize the effects of osmosis. This serves as a practical demonstration of the process in plant cells.
samples.question: How will osmosis be demonstrated in this experiment?

samples.context: After placing the potato cups in water, observations will be made at regular intervals to compare the changes in each potato cup's weight and texture due to osmosis.
samples.question: What will you measure to understand osmosis?

samples.context: The experiment uses potato cups to illustrate osmosis effectively, allowing students to collect data on how different types of potatoes respond to water.
samples.question: What type of data will be collected during the experiment?
